forecast.status_quo_outcome: No attack into Pakistan proper; any violence remains limited to the Line of Control/PAK-administered Kashmir or is non-kinetic/covert.
forecast.no_outcome_scenario: Routine India–Pakistan tensions persist. There may be small-arms or mortar exchanges along the LoC in Kashmir, counterinsurgency operations inside Indian-administered J&K, and harsh rhetoric, but no Indian Armed Forces strike into Sindh, Baluchistan, Punjab, or Khyber Pakhtunkhwa during June 2025.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A major provocation—such as a mass-casualty terror attack inside India credibly linked to Pakistan-based militants—triggers a limited, punitive response. India conducts an airstrike on a camp near Balakot (Khyber Pakhtunkhwa) or a precision artillery/missile strike across the international border into Pakistani Punjab or Baluchistan, reported by reputable media or acknowledged by either side, within June 2025.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline and time window: Kinetic strikes by India into Pakistan proper are rare. The notable modern precedent is the 2019 Balakot airstrike (in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa) following the Pulwama attack; the 2016 ‘surgical strikes’ were across the LoC in Pakistan-administered Kashmir (not in the specified provinces). Given a one-month window, the prior is low absent a precipitating event. The world usually changes slowly, so status quo (no strike) deserves extra weight. 
Escalation incentives and constraints: India has strong incentives to deter cross-border terrorism but faces significant escalation and international diplomatic costs for attacks into Pakistan proper, particularly given the nuclear backdrop. Since the 2021 reaffirmed ceasefire, cross-border firing along the international border has generally been limited; most flare-ups remain on the LoC or within Indian territory. That favors No. 
Why not higher: • No known current trigger of Pulwama-scale severity. • High political/diplomatic/military costs and escalation risks for striking Pakistan proper. • Very narrow time window (June only). 
Why not lower: • There is precedent (2019). • Summer months can coincide with increased infiltration/violence in J&K, which could raise pressure for a visible response. • Domestic political incentives can, in rare cases, favor limited punitive strikes. 
What would raise my forecast: • A mass-casualty attack in India with credible attribution to Pakistan-based groups. • Official Indian attributions and emergency security cabinet meetings; unusual IAF/air-defense readiness; temporary airspace closures; evacuation advisories near the IB; Pakistani alerts or CAPs over K-P/Punjab. • Breakdown of the ceasefire extending from the LoC to the international border. 
What would lower my forecast: • Continued quiet across both the LoC and IB into mid-June. • Clear de-escalatory signaling or productive backchannel/diplomatic engagement. • Absence of any significant terror incidents inside India. 
Research assistant note: No additional information was provided beyond the question background, so this forecast leans on historical base rates, structural incentives, and the short time window.
